message_1: What is the conformal map that transforms the upper-half plane onto the interior of the unit circle preserving the point at infinity?
message_2:
The conformal map that transforms the upper-half plane onto the interior of the unit circle preserving the point at infinity is called the Möbius transformation. It can be defined as follows:

Given the upper-half plane H = {z ∈ ℂ : Im(z) > 0}, the Möbius transformation that maps H onto the interior of the unit circle D = {z ∈ ℂ : |z| < 1} is given by:

f(z) = (z - i)/(z + i),

where z ∈ H and i is the imaginary unit.

This transformation has the properties of being conformal (preserving angles) and maps the point at infinity to the boundary of the unit circle.
